We are given the conditional statement "If the bear was in the cave, then the wolf was in the den" (or "If P, then Q") and the statement "the wolf was in the den" (or Q). To conclude logically, we need to determine if "the bear was in the cave" (or P) follows. Since the conditional statement "If P, then Q" is true and the statement Q is also true, it follows that P must be true. This is because if the condition P is true, then the consequence Q must also be true. Therefore, if Q is true, then P must be true as well.
